Pre-Game Insights: The match promises an explosive cocktail of firepower with the bat, and thrill with the ball.

There's aesthetics in the form of Devon Conway, Rachin Ravindra and Rassie van der Dussen, big-hitting from Henrich Klaasen, David Miller and Glenn Phillips, and the genius of Quinton de Kock to boot.

With the ball, there's pace royalty in the form of Kagiso Rabada, the swing of Trent Boult, the hustle of Gerald Coetzee, and the bounce of Marco Jansen - each of them brings a unique flavour that makes fast bowling thrilling.
New Zealand have made four of the top 20 totals in the tournament, and Rachin Ravindra, Daryl Mitchell and Devon Conway have scored centuries.
South Africa's seven 300-plus totals in a row batting first in ODIs - including four this World Cup - is the longest streak in the game.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The pitch in Pune has been slightly skiddy. Also, the dew factor has played a role in the matches hosted by the MCA Stadium.
The sky will be mostly sunny and clear, with periodic clouds during the match hours in Pune.
Pune is unusually hot and dry for this time of the year, but the surfaces have been good for batting, with even bounce and excellent carry.
Rachin Ravindra's tally of 406 runs is already the most by a New Zealander in his maiden World Cup.
South Africa's pace pack has taken 44 wickets at an average and a strike rate of 23.3 and 23.5, respectively.
Others: The match is more about who goes where in the final four than anything else.
New Zealand's other remaining opponents in the league stage are Pakistan and Sri Lanka.
South Africa will be at Eden Gardens on Sunday for a clash with unbeaten India.
